column1: The images in Bill Henson’s cinematic new book The Liquid Night
column2: derive from work the highly acclaimed artist shot on 35mm colour negative film in New York City in 1989. They present a kaleidoscopic
column3: nocturnal journey through the frenetic

column1: They were shot as formal 35mm frames and served as images in quest of an artistic resolution which Bill Henson became besotted with and which he has now resolved in digital terms creating a compendium of new art which is a recapitulation of a world that has vanished like an all but forgotten dream that tugs at the mind as a set of animated emblems that no longer exist in contemporary reality.
They revisit in the artist’s memory –– and as strange images in the spectator’s –– a world that is the instantiation of time lost and only to be recaptured by the restored function of memory.
Think of a hypnotic time. A jazz bar near Washington Square. The gin and tonic they would bring you like a ritual

column3: and the way they would shift you so that Tony Bennett could be closer to the piano which he was obsessed by. And then you would make your way back to the Algonquin and at midnight (because they closed the doors then) you would have to be let in by the bellhop whose hair turned grey

column5: one more time

At The Beach;Tod Papageorge;FALSE;"In 1975 Tod Papageorge made a cross-America trip that ended on the beaches of Los Angeles. There
column2: taken by the blinding light

column5: on shorter visits

column1: “I think that part of what these beach pictures are about is the difference between our preconceptions of a place and what
column2: when we get there
column3: that place turns out to be. In this case (of Los Angeles and its coastline)
column4: I think it’s also fair to suggest that those preconceptions are particularly strong
column5: shaped as they irresistibly have been by the movies and popular music. So
column6: as a first point
column7: what I wanted to do on this project was examine those preconceptions (at least as I conjured them) through the descriptive power of photography in order to pin down what two semi-myths - the world of surfers and the life of southern California beaches –‘really’ looked like.

column2: if not the medium of photography itself. With these pictures
column3: then
column4: I worked with the belief that the closer I came to describing the literal nature of the place and people I was photographing
column5: the more surprising the pictures that came out of that process might be. All while transforming (I hoped)
column6: the casual
column7: unselfconscious physicality of these beachgoers moving from the boardwalks onto the sand and back again into form and meaning.

column1: “I'm speaking of what I hoped for the photographs

column3: it should go without saying that a good photograph must

column1: Lovers: Ten Years On;Sunil Gupta;FALSE;"In 1984 SUNIL GUPTA’s first long term relationship broke down in shortly after he arrived in London in 1984. He had met his lover in the early 1970’s when the impact of the gay movement upon the consciousness of gay men was just gaining ground.
Then
column2: gay was good
column3: and gay was proud. The laws against gay sex had been turned back. The definition of homosexuality as a psychiatric disorder was successfully challenged. The commercial scene and the visibility of gay men expanded to unprecedented levels. Although
column4: while all this change provided the individual with the means for unstigmatised sexual experimentation in relatively safe venues
column5: simultaneously it hardly dented social attitudes and legal structures which oppressed gay relationships.

column1: The arrival of HIV/AIDS changed all that. Gay men came under attack
column2: from the state and its various channels. The media mounted a vicious campaign to label gay men as sick and irresponsible. Gay men were almost exclusively represented as ill. Patients of some incurable disease that had been equated with their sexuality. On the strength of this fallacy once again there was talk of reinstating repressive laws. Once again “expert medical advisors” were in on the act with their labels and talk of “containment.”

column1: Couples though had come into their own. Gay self-help groups encouraged a change in sexual behaviour and a reduction in the number of partners. However
column2: still without legal recognition
column3: with the new emphasis on monogamy
column4: with social attitudes reverting to hostility and given the invisibility of day-to-day life for gay men within relationships
column5: being a partner in the 1980s proved to be as difficult as it had been decades ago.

column1: “These photographs were made in London. The couples define themselves as such by various criteria; some live together
column2: some don’t
column3: some have been together a short time
column4: some a very long time
column5: and soon. I believe the relationship between gay men is an important but often neglected component central to their lives.” - Sunil Gupta
